My station was a high one once -a king's!- until I was brought very low. I learned among the dregs that men are the same everywhere. Whether they approach you in a back alley reeking of sewer, or the jasmine-scented corridors of royal castles, they smile at you warmly -like friends would- as they fondle their daggers' hilts behind their backs.
Source Hunters here too? Well, if the Legion couldn't save this place, what're you gonna do?

Honoured general

I would like to raise a personal concern of mine, if I may be so bold.

Your prowess in combat is unmatched, your lust for warfare unrivalled. No one doubts this. That prowess served us well (it saved the very world!) but now that the enemy has been vanquished, but for a few straggling legions, is it really necessary to personally command our armies still?

I know your presence inspires our troops, but I worry and enemy spear or arrow may find you yet, just like, with permission, the enemy has found another general before.

To lose you now would devastate nations. My advice would be to exercise caution. Now that peace is almost upon us and our total victory inevitable, there is no need any more for such ferocious heroics. We no longer have need of you as a general: we have need of you as a statesman!

Please think on that.

Signed,
Harald Sigurdson, Duke of Orcha

Much like making love, comedy requires equal parts passion and delivery. Fever for the stage is not enough-- no no! The truly successful comedian will study the details of the craft through countless long, lonely nights in preparation for his rendezvous with the audience!

Compiled within this volume are some of Rivellon's finest funnies-- enough to make a granite statue grin!During a Dwarven funeral, the bearers of the casket accidentally bump into a wall and hear a faint moan.

They open the casket and find out that the Dwarven woman inside is actually alive! The entire funeral party rejoices, and a joyful tear springs into her husband's eye.

The Dwarven lady lives for 10 more years and then dies. There is another funeral for her. At the end of the service, the bearers carry out the casket.

As they are walking out, the husband cries out, 'Watch out for the wall!'An Elf and an Orc show up in Hall of Echoes at the same time. The Orc says he froze to death, and the Elf says he died of a heart attack.

'How did that happen?' asks the Orc.

The Elf replied 'Well, I came home and thought I heard my wife in bed with someone else. But when I searched the house, I couldn't find anybody.

I was so stricken with remorse for wrongly accusing my wife of infidelity, I had a heart attack and died on the spot!'

'Geez,' says the Orc. 'If you'd opened the ice box, we'd both be alive right now!'Every ten years, the Elven Wood Priests in the High Monastery are allowed to break their vow of silence to speak two words.

Ten years go by and it’s one priest’s first chance. He thinks for a second before saying, 'Food bad.'

Ten years later, he says, 'Bed hard.'
It’s the big day, a decade later. He gives the head priest a long stare and says, 'I quit.'

'I’m not surprised,' the Elven High Priest says. 'You’ve been complaining ever since you got here.'

Truth be told, I relish in their stubbornness. Give me bloody combat! Give me the thrill of the frontline! I shall be the first to break their ranks and the last to the leave the battlefield!

But you, you've been absent lately. It goes without saying I prefer to see you by my side.

We shall meet again at the funeral I suppose. Until then, I bid you adieu.

This excerpt from the traditional drama "Genesis of Cyseal" is commonly performed in the local theatre.

Most Cysealians, and even a few foreigners, are amply familiar with the tale and refuse to tolerate deviations from the script most know by heart.


The story goes that two adventurers (lovers, too), Cyrus and Sealia, sailed west from Ferol, knowing not whether they would find land on the other side.

They took with them sufficient provisions for five months of travel, but only during the last week of sixth month did they land upon the land they would come to call "Cyseal".Sealia: Enough, Cyrus! I can't take another moment aboard this death-barge. I'm starving and I'm sick! Will we find no safe refuge from our travails?

Cyrus: My gods... could it be? There... look!

Sealia: What is it? Are we out of fresh water? Is there a leak in the hull?

Cyrus: Look, Seal-- there! Beyond the mist! It's... it's...

Sealia: Land!

Cyrus: Land, my sweet! Land at last! And we shall call it... Cyseal.

I did... 'Yes', I hissed, fool that I was! I should have died that day, but instead I fell into a stupor and awoke in a different realm of Rivellon bereft of all my wealth, and with my soul betrothed to a demon's debauchery that would be ten centuries in the making. But it had also kept its promise -that life-ceding obscenity of a creature- for I was my young, my healthy self again.
We won't see eye to eye much longer!

Esteemed general, esteemed sovereign

As you know, the vanquished Void lives still, be it caged in the imperishable Godbox. We all fear it greatly, for it remains powerful even in confinement. The gods have told us: 'we need Guardians! We need immortals that will safeguard the Godbox and thereby safeguard our world forever.' I can think of no better candidates than the two heroes that were the Void's first undoing.

What say you, my sovereign? Will you heed the call of the divines? And will your honourable companion do the same?

Signed,
Henry, son of William, righteous king of Ferol

My true name is Nick. In life, I was an entertainer aboard the ship of the famed Pontius Pirate. I once dared to defy him, and he savagely beheaded me for the attempt!

To Whom It May Concern (preferably an imp),

I, Grumio, son of Gromio, have made new strides in the fields of fashion, engineering and Things-That-Go-BOOM!

Colours are hidden in my jars, but they do more than dye: they DESTRUCT when used for purposes more entertaining than vogue and vagary! Just combine them with empty grenades and you'll soon see for yourself...

The design of wands too -them nifty wizards' tools- I have improved to great and unique effects. Little do those one-trick-pony magicians know how an impalytical mind like mine outshines them O so brightly! A specially crafted sprocket is all one needs to add powerful attributes to inert wands. What fun, what jolly mischief the results!

So rejoice, dear reader, for you have learned some of the secrets of Grumio!

The honourable generals baffle me! Their behaviour has become puzzling and erratic. They are the saviours of our realm; they are worshipped by Man and Divinity alike, yet they wander down strange and solitary paths.

Word has reached me today that one of them has gone. Vanished! Why, I wonder, why would they do such a thing now that the very world is theirs to command?

And the other... Such force, such sudden ruthlessness. Such tyranny... A betrayal, almost, of the principles they fought for.

These tidings sadden me beyond compare. I think of what could have been and despair. What is it -there must be an answer!- what is it that riles them so?

Signed,
Lady Helena, countess of Leliyalint

We now know the full tale of Arhu's troubled history. He was born a cat and turned into a man by the Sourceress Cassandra. They lived and loved in her lonely tower within the castle of her brother Braccus Rex. When the Source Hunters came to kill Braccus, Arhu helped Cassandra to escape; she fled to a forest where she now holds sway. It was a difficult decision that he has had to live with ever since, and it because of it, it is now more than likely we in turn will have to face the lich.

All of Rivellon thanks you; all of Rivellon is in your debt! Gods and kings bow before you both and it is right and proper that they do so! Even they had thought all was lost: that the world was to meet its end - but you turned the tide.

Many have fallen (so very, very many!) and I know you have suffered a great personal loss as well. Know, generals, that I sympathise deeply. So let us meet in the Hall of Heroes, both to celebrate and to remember: to honour the living and to honour the dead!

Signed,
Henry, son of William, righteous king of Ferol

Alessa! She died so that we might live. She faced the Void with equanimity while we cowered like children. During that final battle against the Void itself we were the last three still standing. In victory, she should have been the last ONE standing. Instead the two of *us* stood: victorious, but false in victory.

I was so fearful; petrified almost in the knowledge that I might see... *him*... again. You see, I knew the mad king. In fact, I... served him.

My friend and ally

It couldn't be, but of course it was. The one I was to marry: HER child, Alessa's child. There simply is no escape from the past. At first I rode headlong into battle, hoping the enemy's sword would do what I could not. Then came the distractions of power. To no avail.

I must admit the truth to myself, here on paper, like I almost did in my previous letter:

Three of us faced the Void Dragon and two of us, myself included, were overcome by terror. When it truly mattered, when the fate of worlds hung in the balance we failed our duty.

It was she who restored our fraying minds. Oh, such mighty wizardry I had never seen! But it spent her, weakened her - and the Void preys on the weak...

It killed her before we could strike back. Only then did we cage it. We won; we saved the world; we were heroes! NO. We were cowards when the moment came.

Now all I can do is become a Guardian. It is the only way both to serve and to forget. I'm certain you feel the same.

The Inquisitor strolled through the town’s silent streets. 'One among you is a practitioner of dark magic. Show yourself.' As the words faded, a shadow emerged from the far end of the square. 'Another foolish Source Hunter?' it called. 'Run off while you can. This town is mine.' The Inquisitor stood firm. 'No longer.' In the distance, the dark mage's fingertips glowed sickly green. 'Then die.' Green sparks traced spiralling arcs towards the Inquisitor, though none hit their mark as it darted forward. One fist sent the Sourcerer sprawling. 'Nicely done,' the figure croaked, 'but at this range I won't miss!' His hand had only begun to blaze green once more as the Inquisitor sent an arc of electricity into the dark mage's chest. 'Neither will I'.

When you read this I will have departed. It had to be. Sovereignty is fast becoming a curse. It was always *her* specialty, not mine. So all of it is yours: the glory and the power. For myself I seek only the inner peace I cannot possibly find in cities or in palaces. I know you'll understand.

To all the world I'll be unreachable, but you know the secret ways and your letters will find me still should you wish them to.

So goodbye! Goodbye and good luck!

The Ultimate Guide to Noxious Bulbs

Noxious bulbs grow in the temperate, forested areas of Rivellon. They don't need much sun to thrive, but they thrive in open areas. Commonly used as a means of security, noxious bulbs are well known for their vivid colours and their equally vivid defence mechanisms.
The plant feeds off of elemental minerals in the soil. Once they are full grown, they appear in a multitude of variations. The effects of the bulbs are independent of their looks. Thus, trial and error is the best method for testing the defences of each bulb.
Still, the colours of the flowers represent the element they are most susceptible to. For instance, the influence of noxious fire bulbs on their surroundings diminish once you cast a fire spell on them. This principle also applies to the noxious water bulb, noxious earth bulb and noxious wind bulb. They are very sturdy flowers that are hard to destroy or uproot, but if one does manage to destroy them, they will hardly go down without a boom.

I myself wouldn't have elected to make my home in this dank little corner of the Phantom Forest, but far be it from me to argue with the Conduit.

At least I've found myself a quiet little place to call my own. Quiet now that I've made use of its previous occupants, that is. A woman and her husband-- they hardly fought at all.

All the better for me. Once they were dead, I found a lovely little spell to use on their corpses. An ancient Immaculate incantation, and a most useful one at that (so useful, in fact, that I've infused these very pages with its power). With it I proved that even cold corpses could be turned toward the greater good.

The Conduit will be extremely pleased. This is exactly the sort of spell she needs for her Tenebrium mines.

The method is simple: A totem of bone serves as the anchor; the spell serves as the guide. A simple pentagram unites totem and spell to ensnare or release the selected souls.

The souls of the deceased are trapped within the totem, and the fate of their corpses is guided by the spell. So long as the totem remains intact, their souls are caged and bound within this realm. This pair-- Charla and Hortun, as I recall-- were infused with the will to trade. Creating an army of miners should be all the easier.

I must tell the priests within the mine to guard their totem well. I'll keep mine on my person, but in the wrong hands the Conduit's entire workforce could disappear.
I passed the initiation, same as the rest, but I haven't sacrificed anything bigger than a sheep as yet! I've got to prove to Lady Attenberah that I've got what it takes...
These stones may be valuable to us, but they are not us ourselves. Leandra cannot stop us from hunting her down.

In victory, life has taken an unreal turn. Everywhere I go, it seems, I am revered not unlike a god. People feel graced when I look them in the eye, considering it a blessing. Children try to touch my hand or sleeve believing it will bring them good luck. The absurdity of it all is staggering.

Above all I wish I had more time to myself: some much needed peace of mind now that peace is finally in sight.

My fellow general

I understand your frustration, though the one that plagues me is of a different nature.

All this attention... Curse it! All these expectations... To hell with them! To be a ruler, it is like being the queen of a beehive. Nobility, ambassadors, citizens, clergy: they scurry about me in endless numbers, buzzing, buzzing, pleading, begging, hanging on to my every word - mindless!

I spend my life in halls and chambers, the light of day almost a memory. I long for the hills, for the fields, the quiet and solitude of the wilds. Couldn't I simply leave... Leave it all behind?
